content:
The Act titled "America's Border Security Act of 2007" includes provisions for technological assets. The Act "America's Border Security Act of 2007" mandates increased use of Department of Defense equipment like UAVs and radars to aid in border surveillance to prevent illegal immigration. A report detailing current equipment usage must be submitted to Congress within 6 months of the Act's enactment. The Act mandates increased use of Department of Defense equipment for border surveillance. A report to Congress must include current equipment usage, a plan to increase equipment use, and types of support to be provided. During a 1-year period, the Secretary of Homeland Security will conduct a pilot program using unmanned aerial vehicles for border surveillance along the Canada-US border. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2008 through 2012 to support this initiative. SEC. 3. INFRASTRUCTURE.

The Secretary of Homeland Security will construct roads, acquire barriers, and facilities to control US borders. Quarterly progress reports will be submitted to Congress, and appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2008-2012.

SEC. 4. PORTS OF ENTRY. The Secretary of Homeland Security is authorized to construct additional ports of entry along the international land borders of the United States and make necessary improvements to existing ports of entry. SEC. 5. SECURE COMMUNICATION.

The Secretary of Homeland Security will develop a plan to enhance satellite communication for Border Patrol agents and other agencies for clear and secure communication. This includes communication between agents, stations, residents in remote areas, and other law enforcement agencies.

SEC. 6. UNMANNED AERIAL VEHICLES. SEC. 6. UNMANNED AERIAL VEHICLES.

The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to acquire and maintain at least 5 unmanned aerial vehicles and related equipment for patrolling the US international borders. This includes additional sensors, critical spares, satellite command and control, and other necessary operational support equipment. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2008 and 2009 to fund these acquisitions. SEC. 7. SURVEILLANCE TECHNOLOGIES PROGRAMS. The Secretary of Homeland Security must develop and implement an aerial surveillance program using unmanned aerial vehicles to enhance border security with Canada and Mexico within 90 days of the enactment of the Act. The program aims to continuously monitor every mile of the international borders. The Secretary of Homeland Security must develop an aerial surveillance program to monitor every mile of the international borders with Canada and Mexico. The program will assess and consult on aerial surveillance technologies to address border threats, including consultation with the Secretary of Defense on deploying technologies along the borders. The Secretary of Homeland Security must consult with the Secretary of Defense on deploying technologies along international borders and with the Federal Aviation Administration on safety and airspace coordination for the aerial surveillance program. The program will use various aerial surveillance technologies in different terrains to evaluate border threats. The Secretary of Homeland Security will evaluate surveillance technologies in various terrains near international borders to assess their effectiveness, cost, and privacy concerns for border security. The Secretary of Homeland Security may continue using aerial surveillance technologies for border security while assessing their effectiveness. Within 180 days of implementing the program, a report must be submitted to Congress with program details and recommendations for improvement. Authorization of appropriations is also included. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to establish a program for border surveillance using various technologies to create a "virtual fence" along the international borders of the United States. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this program. The Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program aims to establish a "virtual fence" along the US international borders using integrated technologies for operational control. The program includes motion sensor alerts and cameras that automatically pan and tilt towards triggered sensors. The Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program includes motion sensor alerts and cameras that automatically pan and tilt towards triggered sensors. Cameras do not need manual operation, have flexible views, and can be viewed at designated centers. Data collection, cataloging, and reporting follow a standard process, and future technology upgrades can be integrated with existing systems. The Program aims to report intrusion and response data, integrate future surveillance technology upgrades, develop performance measures to evaluate effectiveness, streamline site selection processes, and establish standards for the Program. The Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program aims to streamline site selection, validation, and environmental assessment processes to minimize delays in installing surveillance technology infrastructure. Standards are developed to expand shared use of existing structures and deploy nonpermanent or mobile surveillance platforms for increased mobility in identifying illegal border intrusions. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to report to Congress within one year of the program's initial implementation. The Secretary of Homeland Security must report to Congress within one year of implementing the Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program, including a description of the program and any recommendations for improvement. Standards are set for evaluating contractors providing goods or services for the program. The Inspector General of the Department reviews new contracts for the Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program over $5,000,000 to ensure compliance with cost requirements, performance objectives, and schedules, reporting findings to the Secretary of Homeland Security promptly. The Inspector General reviews contracts for the Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program over $5,000,000, reporting findings to the Secretary of Homeland Security. The Secretary must submit a report to the Senate and House Committees within 30 days, detailing any actions taken in response to the findings. Authorization of appropriations is also mentioned. The Inspector General reviews contracts for the Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program over $5,000,000, reporting findings to the Secretary of Homeland Security. The Secretary must submit a report detailing any actions taken in response to the findings. Authorization of appropriations is also mentioned. SEC. 8. HIRING AND TRAINING OF BORDER AND TRANSPORTATION SECURITY PERSONNEL. During fiscal year 2008, the Secretary of Homeland Security is required to increase the number of full-time agents and support staff in the Bureau of Immigration and Customs Enforcement by 400, and the number of full-time inspectors and support staff in the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection by 600. The Secretary is authorized to waive any limitation on personnel to fulfill these requirements. Training for these personnel is also mandated. The Secretary of Homeland Security is authorized to waive limitations on personnel to increase staff in the Department of Homeland Security. Training is required for agents, inspectors, and support staff to utilize new technologies and maintain proficiency levels for border protection. SEC. 9. NATIONAL BORDER SECURITY PLAN. The Secretary of Homeland Security must prepare and submit a National Border Security Plan to Congress by January 31 each year. The plan must include a vulnerability assessment of each port of entry on the northern or southern border, and consultation with relevant law enforcement agencies and private entities is required. Port security coordinators may be established at these entry points. The Secretary of Homeland Security may establish port security coordinators at ports of entry on the northern or southern border to assist with vulnerability assessments and preparation of required plans.
